abstractText: Due to extensive applications of microfluidic devices, manufacturing of these apparatus has recently been noticed. Production of multiple emulsions is one of the main goals of manufacturing microfluidic devices. Design and fabrication of microfluidics are functions of the size of emulsion droplets, properties of fluids applied for emulsification, and considered stability for emulsions. In this article, we have manufactured a novel microfluidic device using simple fabrication and accessible materials. Capillary tubes, PTFE (polytetrafluoroethylene) chassis, a medical needle of gauge 32, and O-rings are the primary materials used to produce this device. The production procedure is explained completely, and all the drawings are represented. Concerning probable interactions between glues and flowing fluids, we tried to fabricate and seal the device without applying chemical agents. The device is tested by n-heptane and deionized water to produce multiple water-in-oil-in-water (W/O/W) emulsions. A sensitivity analysis on the rate of injection is performed. Considering the HLB (hydrophilic–lipophilic balance) as an important property of emulsifiers, the effects of two different types of emulsifiers (sodium dodecyl sulfate with HLB of 40 and glycerol monostearate with HLB of 3.8) at various concentrations are investigated. Due to the results, the injection rate of the mediate phase should be less than half of the outer phase for the formation of emulsions. Consequently, the rate of injection for the inner phase should be less than half of that for the mediate phase. The simplicity of production and accessible raw materials could be considered as the strengths of our microfluidic device. I. INTRODUCTION
Multiple emulsions have extensive applications in the food industry, drug delivery, and lubricants.1 The existence of a shell in multiple emulsions enables these fluids to protect the core material at various conditions. A shell phase surrounds the core material, and the shell phase is emulsified in a carrier phase.2 Multiple emulsions could be oil in water in oil (O/W/O) or water in oil in water (W/O/W). Indeed, in multiple emulsions, a water phase is located between two oily phases or vice versa. Multiple emulsions are common systems for encapsulating variable materials, which should be applied to a specific environment, condition, or organ.3
Although some useful food ingredients are necessary for the body, they have an inappropriate smell and taste. Flavoring and
changing the taste of foods is one of the applications of multiple emulsions.4
Each drug has a particular goal and should be delivered to a specific organ, while the drug could be adsorbed to the other organs during digestion. To avoid this phenomenon, the drug materials should be capsulated and covered by different shell materials. In fact, the drugs are protected by shell material to secure their delivery to the goal organ of the body.5 Designing the core–shell system should be performed concerning the conditions at the goal organ and other organs. The shell should be resistant to the situation of other organs, and it should be degraded by unique conditions at the goal organ. Multiple emulsions are assumed to be efficient solutions for drug delivery.6
In addition, with respect to existence of harsh conditions in oil reservoirs multiple emulsions and encapsulated materials could

be used to avoid production of formation water, visous fingering and for EOR purposes.7,8 Multiple emulsions could be produced at specific conditions. Appropriate emulsifiers, proper shear stress, and emulsification method are determinative factors in the formation of emulsions.9 The application of microfluidic devices to produce multiple emulsions has recently been noticed.10 Designing the microfluidic devices is performed by various methods and with respect to the goals of projects. Several criteria, such as accuracy of machining, assembling, sealing, and closed tolerance, should be considered through designing and manufacturing microfluidic devices.11 In addition, preventing the probable interactions between materials of microfluidic devices and phases used for emulsification is essential.12
The formation of emulsion in a microfluidic device is a function of various parameters, same as the injection rate of each phase, the radius of tubes used in the device, and the rheological properties of fluids. Utada et al. (2005) introduced jet flow and dripping as the flowing regimes of microfluidic devices. The following equations can be used to predict the flowing regime of a capillary device:13
tg = R3jet/Qsum, (1)
tpinch = CRjetηOF/γ. (2)
If tg < tpinch, the flowing regime will be jet. Otherwise, the dripping regime is expected for the device under certain conditions.
Configuration and manufacturing of microfluidic devices have been the subject of some research in the past decade. These devices mainly consist of three main paths or tubes for the flowing carrier phase, shell phase, and core fluid.14 Although the mechanism of emulsification through microfluidic devices is similar in all types of manufactured devices, the devices differ in the type of assembling, sort, and dimension of the tubes and the method of production.
Bandulasena et al. (2019) designed a microfluidic device to generate multiple emulsions. Round capillary glasses were considered as the tubes of microfluidic devices. They manufactured three blocks as locations of tubes by polyacetal for coupling the tubes into them. The polyacetal blocks can be attached to each other by LEGO-type connections. The device is tested with deionized water as the water phase and mineral oil as the oil phase. The successful formation of W/O/W multiple emulsions is reported.15
Using 3D-printed patterns for manufacturing microfluidic devices is common.16 Martino et al., in 2014, introduced their microfluidic device, which was printed using a 3D printer. To test the device, they used deionized water as the inner and outer fluids and mineral oil as the middle phase. The device worked properly during the test process. Due to the enclosed tolerance of 3D printers, these devices are highly accurate.17 However, the raw materials used for 3D printers are mainly soluble in some inorganic fluids (e.g., benzene, n-hexane, and toluene). In addition, their surface quality is not high enough for accurate visual observations.
Li et al. (2013) manufactured a microfluidic device by using resin epoxy, a capillary tube, and microscope slides. Lower cost, simple fabrication, and the ability to observe under the microscope are the positive points of their device. Difficult cleaning and the application of high-tech tools for drilling the glass could be considered weak points. Their device successfully passed the tests of production of multiple emulsions.18
FIG. 1. Front view of the manufactured microfluidic device.
Some microfluidics work by T-junction structures. The wettability of the surface of channels plays a key role in these types of microfluidics.19 First, the desired pattern is carved on a plastic sticker using a laser instrument. Thereafter, the sticker is pasted on a clean glass, and by using diluted HF (hydrofluoric) acid, the dissolution of the glass takes place. There is no interaction between HF acid and plastic, while it can dissolve glass at a limited level. Finally, the sticker is removed, and another glass plate is etched on the surface of the main glass by the thermal etching process. Inexpensive fabrication and high accuracy in carving the pattern are known as the main positive points of these devices. Cleaning and washing are the main challenges of T-junction microfluidics. In addition, the uncontrolled rate of dissolution is another limitation of manufacturing microfluidic devices with this method. The uncontrolled rate of dissolution results in uncertainty in the diameter of flowing paths.
The direction of flowing phases is also an important criterion in designing microfluidic devices. All phases could flow co-currently and in the same direction. On the contrary, at least two of them could flow in opposite directions (countercurrently). It should be noted that, finally, all fluids will be moved in the same direction in the outlet of the device. The direction of movement can affect the force that is exerted on each fluid.20
Overcoming the severities, limitations, and challenges against the production of previous devices, a microfluidic device is designed and manufactured in this research. The mediate and outer fluids flow countercurrently. The availability of materials, simple fabrication (without using chemical agents), and preventing probable interactions between fluids and device materials are considered the main criteria for design. The exerted shear stress and shear rate to fluids in each tube are calculated. Figure 1 represents the manufactured microfluidic device.

sections.heading: A. Tubes
sections.text:
The manufactured device consists of three capillary tubes for the flow of fluids: a main tube, an injection tube, and a collection tube.
The main tube is a path for the flowing carrier phase and the fluid, which is assumed to be a shell. The fluids will flow countercurrently through this tube. In addition, both injection and collection capillary tubes are located at the center of the main tube. The flowing fluids should meet each other at the inlet of the collection tube. In other words, the head of the main tube is the inlet for the carrier

phase, and the other head is the inlet for the entrance of the shell phase.
The injection tube is considered the path for the transportation of the fluid, which is used as the core. This tube should be aligned in the center of the main tubes. The core fluid will be pumped to the device from the inlet of this tube. The outlet of the injection tube faces the inlet of the collection tube at the center of the main tube.
Multiple emulsions (capsules) will be formed at the inlet of the collection tube. The collection tube is the path for leaking them out. In other words, the emulsification or encapsulation will take place at the inlet collection tube. The core phase will be surrounded by the shell phase with the help of shear stress at the inlet of the collection tube. The collection tube and the injection tube should be aligned symmetrically and longitudinally at the center of the main tube.
The visibility of the emulsification procedure and flow stream introduced glass capillary tubes as a suitable candidate for flowing paths. The sizes of the selected tubes are summarized in Table I. To apply more shear stress on the core phase and sequentially have better control of this fluid, the outlet of the injection tube should be tighter than the inlet of the collection tube. In addition, the size of the injection tube nozzle has a direct effect on the size of core droplets. Since the aim of manufacturing this microfluidic device is to generate micro-multiple emulsions, the inner diameter of the injection and collection tubes should be in the micron range. To obtain a nozzle-like edge and conical form at the outlet of the injection tube and raise the pressure, a tube with 100 μm inner diameter was heated above a flame symmetrically and pulled out mechanically (as tight as possible). Based on the design criteria, the outlet diameter of the injection tube should be lower than 100 μm. As pulling the tube above the flame did not have enough accuracy to create a homogeneous conic, a medical needle with gauge 32 was coupled at the outlet of the injection tube (at the conical head). The dimensions and properties of the needle gauge 32 are summarized in Table II.
Obviously, the internal diameter of the main tube should be greater than the outer diameters of the injection and collection tubes. The differences between the internal diameter of the main tube and the outer diameters of the injection and collection tubes should not be as high to let injection and collection move freely in the vertical

Fixing the position of tubes is of high importance. Centralizing and alignment of the injection tube and collection tube have great effects on the emulsification process.13 To exert extra pressure on the drops injected from the outlet of the injection tube, the inner diameter at the inlet of the collection tube should be lower than the body of the tube. In other words, an orifice should be created at the inlet of the collection tube. This pressure prevents the continuous flow of each phase. Therefore, the inlet of the collection tube was heated symmetrically for some seconds on the direct flame. Figure 2 schematically represents the arrangement of the tubes.

sections.heading: B. Chassis
sections.text:
The device includes four chassis. The chassis is the location of the tubes. The injection and collection tubes should be fixed to their unique chassis (bolts), while the main tube will be held by two chassis (nuts). To avoid probable interactions of flowing fluids and coupling materials, such as glue and paste, chemical agents are not recommended for assembling the device. The tip of the injection and collection tubes is kept by two bolts, and the bolts will be tightened onto their nuts. The nuts are the chassis for coupling the main tube. Figure 3 represents the 3D schematic of the designed chassis. Two sets of bolts and nuts should be manufactured. The selected material for chassis (bolts and nuts) is PTFE (polytetrafluoroethylene). Due to the activity of chemical agents that might be used in this system, PTFE is selected to avoid interactions with normal chemical (non-acidic) agents. Thermal expansion and contraction of PTFE, on the one hand, and its elasticity, on the other hand, were additional reasons for this selection. As another positive point, machining operation on PTFE is easier than for other materials.
Figure 4 illustrates the drawings of nuts and their dimensional details. As is observed in Fig. 3, the main tube should be fixed at position E. The drawings of bolts, which are designed for coupling the collection and injection tubes, are shown in Figs. 5 and 6, respectively.

sections.heading: C. Pins
sections.text:
Four metal pins were designed and manufactured for connecting the chassis to pumps. In fact, the pins are the inlets and outlets of the device. So, the fluids will enter and exit the system by pins. Avoiding any interaction between pin material and chemical fluids, the pins were made up of stainless steel 316. Two sets of identical pins are manufactured for different locations. Two special pins were manufactured for bolts to transmit the fluids into the injection and collection tubes [Fig. 7(a)]. The pins must be installed at point D (Fig. 3). The inlet of these pins has an internal diameter of 5 mm, and the internal diameter of the pins reduces to 1 mm at the outlet. The reduction in the diameter in the length of these pins is designed to exert more pressure on the flowing fluid. In addition, two pins with an internal diameter of 1 mm and an outer diameter of 5 mm were produced for connecting to the nuts [Fig. 7(b)]. The transmission of fluids from the pump to the nuts and then the main tube is performed by these pins. These pins will be installed at point C (Fig. 3). Figure 7 represents the drawings of pins. The

sections.heading: E. Fabrication
sections.text:
As mentioned above, the connections and couplings should be governed without the application of any chemical agents, such as
FIG. 6. Drawing of the bolt designed for coupling the injection tube.
glues. Moreover, complete sealing is vital for couplings and connections due to the flow of fluids through this device. Therefore, we decided to couple the glass tubes into the chassis with fitting. The holes were drilled with diameters equal to the outer diameters of their relative glass tubes and tolerances of ±0.01 mm. The coupling process was performed by warming the chassis with hot water and cooling the glass tubes with liquid nitrogen. Using the expansion and shrinkage properties of chassis and glass, the tubes were placed at their loci. In addition, the pins were installed on the chassis by the same method. To attach the needle gauge 32 at the tip of the injection tube, the plastic part at the end of the needle was fitted to the conical tip of the injection tube and held at the center. Then, by heating the plastic, it took the form of a conical shape of an injection tube.

sections.heading: F. Designing criteria
sections.text: The diameters of the bolts were 20 mm with a screw step of 1 mm. This screw step was selected to enhance the accuracy of movement. By this screw step, each full revolution of the bolt in the nut results in 1 mm traveling backward or forward.

sections.heading: G. O-rings
sections.text:
Two O-rings are needed for sealing the joints of injection tubenut and collection tube-nut. These O-rings are installed to achieve a fair seal at the front region of the nuts. Therefore, any leakage of the middle and outer phases is avoided. The O-rings’ outer diameter should be the same as their location and even a bit greater, while their inner diameter should be the same as the outer diameter of their related tubes and even a little tighter.
Canol cutting by wire cut: Since the tip of all available medical needles is inclined with respect to the importance of a flat tip for injection tubes, it is vital to cut the tip of the needle vertically. As

sections.heading: H. Experimental evaluation
sections.text:
Several experiments were designed to check the performance of the device. The emulsification process was recorded using a Dino camera. The flow of fluids into the injection, collection, and main tubes has been investigated by three syringe pumps simultaneously. The wetting properties of tubes may have key roles in the emulsification process. Before entering the collection tube, the mediate fluid flows through the annulus between the outer surface of the injection tube and the inner surface of the main tube, while the channel between the outer surface of the collection tube and the inner surface of the main tube belongs to the carrier fluid (outer phase). It is obvious that the wetting properties of the surfaces should be in confirmation with the connecting fluid. The state of wettability of the inner surface of the collection tube should be the same as the outer phase. If we need to produce W/O/W, the wettability of this region should be water-wet. As we know, the natural wettability for glass surfaces is water-wet.
To evaluate the performance of the device, a series of experiments were designed. Sensitivity analyses on flow rate and type of emulsifier have been performed during this stage. The generation of W/O/W emulsions was the final goal of the experiment design. Deionized water (DIW) and N-heptane were used as water and oil phases, respectively. Due to the clarity of DIW and N-heptane, a very low amount of dye oil-based color (Sudan red) was added to
N-heptane to distinguish the oil phase. The fluids entered the system using three syringe pumps. Obtaining the appropriate injection rate, the flow rate of each phase was varied, and with respect to the observations, the fair flow rates were specified. Generally, the flow rate of the outer phase should be greater than the mediate phase, and consequently, the inner phase should have the lowest flow rate. This rule was obeyed during our experiments.
Since the oil phase is placed in the middle of two water phases, the dispersion of emulsifiers in both the oil and water phases is of importance. So, the HLB (Hydrophilic–Lipophilic Balance) of emulsifiers should be considered in the experiments. The greater value of the HLB index indicates more hydrophilicity. In contrast, emulsifiers with an HLB index between 1 and 4 are known as hydrophobic. We tested SDS (sodium dodecyl sulfate) with an HLB of 40 as a hydrophilic emulsifier and glycerol monostearate with an HLB of 3.8 as the hydrophobic one. If the emulsifier is dispersed in the oil phase homogeneously, a suitable generation of multiple emulsions will be expected.

sections.heading: A. Equivalent shear stress
sections.text:
The calculation of exerted shear stress on fluids is of importance. The values of shear stress and shear rate present a better insight into the flowing behavior of each fluid. The force that is applied parallel to the flowing direction or cross section of fluids is known as shear stress, and it could be calculated by the following general formula:
τ = μ( ∂u ∂y ), (3)
where μ is the dynamic viscosity, u is the velocity, y is the thickness of the cross-area, and τ represents the shear stress. The higher values of shear stress show a greater exerted force and, consequently, a higher pressure.

γ̇ = v h , (4)
where v is the velocity of fluid flow, h is the distance at the perpendicular axis, and γ̇ represents the shear rate in Eq. (4). As can be seen, the value of the shear rate can be increased by increasing the velocity or reducing the diameter of the pipe. Therefore, the shear rate is not an intrinsic property of the fluid, and it only depends on the condition of flow. Table V represents the shear rate and shear stress in each experiment.
The injection rate and the diameter of tubes are two important parameters in the final state of formed emulsions. Shear rate and shear stress are directly in contact with both of these parameters. Thus, the shear rate and shear stress are effective in the formation of multiple emulsions. Indeed, the shear rate and shear stress have key roles in emulsification at the collection tube. It is obvious that reducing the size of emulsions is highly dependent on the injection rate and, consequently, a function of shear rate and shear stress. Varying the injection rate can help us to have O/W emulsions with medium-sized oil phase droplets. Achievement of the smaller size of emulsions and multiple emulsions is impossible without the application of emulsifiers. Since the emulsification process takes place in the collection tube, the values of shear rate and shear stress in this tube are of importance. The minimum shear rate exerted on the oil phase and outer water phase for obtaining O/W emulsions with mediumsize droplets is 8149 and 16 298 s−1, respectively. The size of oil phase droplets could be reduced by the addition of emulsifiers. However, the shear rate exerted on the inner water phase at the collection tube should be at least 4074.5 s−1 for the formation of W/O/W multiple emulsions in the presence of an appropriate amount of emulsifiers.
Not only the aforementioned parameters affect the emulsification procedure, but also other parameters such as alignment and
centralizing of capillary tubes, wettability of surface of flowing paths, and viscosity of each phase can influence the process significantly.

sections.heading: IV. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text:
With respect to available equipment and materials, a microfluidic device is designed and manufactured. The device has been tested to find out its efficiency in the production of multiple emulsions. Fabrication and sealing without glues or pastes extended its applications to be used in many fluids. During the experimental procedure, it was clarified that the emulsifiers with lower HLB are proper for the generation of W/O/W multiple emulsions. In fact, the emulsifiers with lower HLB can produce W/O/W with a lower concentration in comparison with high HLB emulsifiers. Spreading this emulsifier in the oil phase, on the one hand, and the presence of the oil phase between two water phases, on the other hand, enhance the efficiency of emulsifiers with lower HLB values.
In addition, the effects of injection rate were also investigated. It was observed that varying the rate of injection can reduce the size of O/W emulsions up to a specified value. A further reduction in the size of droplets and the generation of W/O/W multiple emulsions take place in the presence of emulsifiers. Shear rate and shear stress are introduced as important parameters with determinative roles. For the investigated system (DIW, n-heptane, and DIW) and in the presence of an appropriate amount of emulsifiers, the multiple emulsions will be formed at shear stress equal to 145.05, 31.69, and 36.26 Pa for inner, mediate, and outer phases, respectively. Therefore, we have to tune the injection rate to achieve shear stress above the mentioned values.
